FacilityName: The Andersons, Inc. - Wisconsin Rapids Terminal

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Storage Tanks, Pumps, Compressors, and Piping

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source [40 CFR 68.155(a)]:
The Andersons is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that encompasses design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training. Robust engineering controls are in place to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. The transloading facility is a non-responding facility for releases of the RMP-listed chemicals, so the site utilizes an Emergency Action Plan.
The stationary source and regulated substances handled [40 CFR 68.155(b)]:
The Wisconsin Rapids facility transloads and stores liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), almost entirely consisted of propane, from rail cars into storage tanks and transports to the customer. The maximum inventory represents 3 storage tanks of LPG and at most 30 rail cars, assuming the contents is entirely propane. 
The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps [40 CFR 68.155(c)]:
The Andersons has a program in place to comply with the provisions of the accidental release prevention regulations under 40 CFR Part 68. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the existing release prevention program.

Process Safety Information [40 CFR Part 68.65]
The Andersons maintains a detailed record of process safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.

Process Hazard Analysis [40 CFR Part 68.67]
Comprehensive analyses ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently. The methodology used to carry out these analyses is HAZOP. The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a regular interval of 5 years. Any findings related to the ha

zard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Written Operating Procedures [40 CFR Part 68.69]
To ensure safe operations, The Andersons maintains detailed written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations and normal shutdown. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

Employee Training [40 CFR Part 68.71]
The Andersons has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating plant processes are competent in the applicable operating procedures. Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.

Mechanical Integrity [40 CFR Part 68.73]
The Andersons carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations. Inspected process equipment include pressure vessels, piping systems, pressure relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices. Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change (MOC) [40 CFR Part 68.75]
Written procedures are in place at The Andersons to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures. Facility operators or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification(s).

Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) [40 CFR Part 68.77]
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and modifications to existing processes are conducted routinely at The Andersons transloading facility. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction

, equipment, operating, and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits [40 CFR Part 68.79]
The Andersons conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the USEPA RMP and OSHA PSM regulations are being implemented. These audits are conducted at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a prompt manner.

Incident Investigation [40 CFR Part 68.81]
The Andersons promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum period of 5 years.

Employee Participation [40 CFR Part 68.83]
The Andersons believes that Process Safety Management and accident prevention is a team effort. Employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, The Andersons employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP and PSM rules, including information resulting from Process Hazard Analyses in particular.

Hot Work Permit [40 CFR Part 68.85]
The Andersons has a hot work permit that requires issuance of a hot work permit for hot work operations conducted on or near the covered process. 

Contractor Safety Program [40 CFR Part 68.87] 
The Andersons occasionally hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is carried out. The Andersons has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards associated with the contractor's work and the corresponding processes. Contractors are als

o informed of all the procedures for emergency response in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.
The five-year accident history [40 CFR 68.155(d)]:
The Andersons transloading facility is a new facility and therefore has not had any accidents.
The emergency response program [40 CFR 68.155(e)]:
In the event of an incident, The Andersons has systems in place to respond quickly. Processes can be shut down on an emergency basis and the facility has a plan in place for evacuations, adequate first aid, and medical treatment and notification of local emergency response agencies. The facility is a non-responding facility, and relies on Wood County Emergency Management to respond to chemical releases.
Planned changes to improve safety [40 CFR 68.155(f)]:
The Andersons is committed to improving our safety systems. In an effort to continually improve our systems, The Andersons has an internal process for reviewing all of our safety systems. Additionally, all process changes regarding the covered process are reviewed by the site management team prior to making any change. This provides expert review from each critical discipline, i.e. personnel safety, environmental, process safety, etc.

The Andersons has completed this report to provide the public with information about our activities at this facility. We believe that the many controls instituted to maintain a safe operation, and our commitment to continuous improvement that an incident affecting our employees or the surrounding area is unlikely to occur.
